comment: :End of year deals . Why do they still happen when work or business run on -7- days , month continuous cycles ? Who motivates these end-of-year artificial deadlines ? Who benefits more from them - buyers or sellers ? Or analysts and advisors who have to work thru holidays ?

comment: Agree . Random deadlines are super weird , but we all run by monthly / quarterly / annual reports or so to evaluate companies and it s all silly . Weirdest for me is open enrollment periods for health insurance or health insurance all together .

comment: The deadlines are not so random , they are very predictable . I'd call them more artificial and forced on us . And our choice to run by them creates artificial incentives and biases that lead to a less than perfect market .
amr:

(m / multi-sentence

            :ARG1 (r / random
                  :polarity -
                  :domain (d / deadline)
                  :degree (s / so))
            :ARG2 (p / possible-01
                  :ARG1 (p2 / predict-01
                        :ARG1 d
                        :degree (v / very))))
      :snt2 (c2 / call-01
            :ARG0 (ii / i)
            :ARG1 d
            :ARG2 (a / artificial
                  :ARG2-of (h / have-degree-91
                        :ARG1 d
                        :ARG3 (m2 / more)))
            :ARG3 (f / force-01
                  :ARG1 d
                  :ARG2 (w / we)))
      :snt3 (a2 / and
            :op2 (c3 / create-01
                  :ARG0 (c4 / choose-01
                        :ARG0 (w2 / we)
                        :ARG1 (r2 / run-01
                              :ARG0 w2
                              :ARG1 d))
                  :ARG1 (a3 / and
                        :op1 (t / thing
                              :ARG0-of (ii2 / incentivize-01))
                        :op2 (t2 / thing

                        :mod (a4 / artificial)

                                    :ARG1-of (p3 / perfect-02)
                                    :ARG1-of (h2 / have-degree-91
                                          :ARG2 (l2 / less)
